awd_titl_txt: InquirySpace 2: Broadening Access to Integrated Science Practices
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will create technology-enhanced classroom activities and resources that increase student learning of science practices in high school biology, chemistry, and physics courses. The project addresses the urgent national priority to improve science education as envisioned in the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) by focusing less on learning facts and equations and instead providing students with the time, skills, and resources to experience the conduct of science and what it means to be a scientist. This project builds on prior work that created a sequence of physics activities that significantly improved students' abilities to undertake data-based experiments and led to productive independent investigations. The goal of the InquirySpace project is to improve this physics sequence, extend the approach to biology and chemistry, and adapt the materials to the needs of diverse students by integrating tailored formative feedback in real time. The result will be student and teacher materials that any school can use to allow students to experience the excitement and essence of scientific investigations as an integral part of science instruction. The project plans to create and iteratively revise learning materials and technologies, and will be tested in 48 diverse classroom settings. The educational impact of the project's approach will be compared with that of business-as-usual approaches used by teachers to investigate to what extent it empowers students to undertake self-directed experiments. To facilitate the widest possible use of the project, a complete set of materials, software, teacher professional development resources, and curriculum design documents will be available online at the project website, an online teacher professional development course, and teacher community sites. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

InquirySpace will incorporate several innovative technological and pedagogical features that will enable students to undertake scientific experimentation that closely mirrors current science research. These features will include (1) educational games to teach data analysis and interpretation skills needed in the approach, (2) reduced dependence on reading and writing through the use of screencast instructions and reports, (3) increased reliance on graphical analysis that can make equations unnecessary, and (4) extensive use of formative feedback generated from student logs. The project uses an overarching framework called Parameter Space Reasoning (PSR) to scaffold students through a type of experimentation applicable to a very large class of experiments. PSR involves an integrated set of science practices related to a question that can be answered with a series of data collection runs for different values of independent variables. Data can be collected from sensors attached to the computer, analysis of videos, scientific databases, or computational models. A variety of visual analytic tools will be provided to reveal patterns in the graphs. Research will be conducted in three phases: design and development of technology-enhanced learning materials through design-based research, estimation of educational impact using a quasi-experimental design, and feasibility testing across diverse classroom settings. The project will use two analytical algorithms to diagnose students' learning of data analysis and interpretation practices so that teachers and students can modify their actions based on formative feedback in real time. These algorithms use computationally optimized calculations to model the growth of student thinking and investigation patterns and provide actionable information to teachers and students almost instantly. Because formative feedback can improve instruction in any field, this is a major development that has wide potential.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the InquirySpace 2 (IS2) project was to support learning science through engagement in scientific inquiry. This was done through iterative development of materials, technology, and teacher supports, and by conducting research on the implementations to inform the educational research and development community.

The IS2 project addressed the following three barriers so that open-ended inquiry can become accessible to a wider range of high school students. 

  • Curriculum Resource Barrier: the lack of student resources designed to develop student ability to undertake open-ended experimentation

  • Tool Barrier: the lack of technological resources that facilitate student engagement with data

  • Pedagogy Barrier: the difficulty teachers face in facilitating classrooms where students are given greater opportunities for agency in designing and conducting experiments

This project worked to remove these barriers through developing and testing a curriculum and pedagogical approach that (1) takes advantage of a platform for data collection and analysis from diverse sources, (2) is built on a new student model of independent investigation, (3) encourages students to work deeply and inquisitively with data through data collection and analysis as part of investigation, and (4) positions teachers as facilitators of developing student agency. 

Curricula IS2 created a set of scaffolded curricular units that build up the necessary practices and skills students need to engage in scientific exploration of phenomena. The curricular sequence in each discipline follows a particular template. There are three investigations for each discipline (physics, chemistry, and biology), which generally follow this structure:

  • Investigation 1 is the most scaffolded, and focuses on learning the basics of data collection and analysis, how to use sensors, and the struggles that come with understanding their limitations.

  • Investigation 2 introduces more advanced features of data organization and analysis while facilitating students? realization that collaborating on exploration of phenomena requires agreement on careful protocols for data collection and experimental design.

  • Investigation 3 has few to no scaffolds. In this investigation, students design their own experiments, bringing the skills and practices they have been using in the previous investigations to bear.

The curricular materials and teacher resources can be found at https://learn.concord.org/inquiryspace.

Tools for student inquiry Technology can play a key role in supporting student inquiry. IS2 developed tools in three key areas: (1) tools for data gathering; (2) computational models for simulating phenomena; and (3) tools for data analysis.

To assist in data gathering, IS2 developed a web-based technology that can interface with both wired and wireless sensors that are most commonly found in today?s classrooms. This in combination with adaptations of the free web-based Common Online Data Analysis Platform (CODAP), allowed students to collect data across many different types of sources, including sensors, simulations, existing public data sets, and manually entered data from experiments, streamlining the inquiry process such that students didn?t need to learn multiple interfaces for data gathering and analysis.

Simulations developed by IS2 allowed students to do many more experiments than might be possible with the time they have to do physical experiments, allowing them to explore more factors that affect the phenomenon under study, explore them more deeply, and quickly test hypotheses.

CODAP, which was designed to facilitate student analysis of data, was further refined with lab experiments in mind to support students in data generation, organization, and analysis. CODAP can be found here: https://codap.concord.org. A set of videos supporting the use of CODAP in a science inquiry context can be found here: http://short.concord.org/lrc. 

Pedagogical Supports To support teachers in facilitating an inquiry-centric learning environment, the project created a professional learning community (PLC), which consisted of monthly whole-group meetings, disciplinary group sub-meetings, and an online asynchronous Schoology group to share resources, ideas about implementing inquiry, and continue conversations beyond the virtual PLC meetings.

Other teacher resources have been posted in the same location as the curricular resources, including extensive educative teacher guides.

Inquiry Framework We created an Inquiry Framework to guide the research and development of this project. This framework blends modeling, inquiry cycles of design, collect, analyze, and explain, and modern conceptions of material resistance. The modeling component relates to student conceptions of the phenomenon under study and the process of scientific inquiry. The inquiry cycle describes non-serial phases of inquiry that happen at multiple scales, from rapid inquiry cycles related to troubleshooting and initial design at the individual level, to community or whole-class inquiry. Material resistance refers to the limitations imposed by the physical setups students use to explore a scientific phenomenon and the measurement tools used to collect data for analysis. The framework can be found here: http://short.concord.org/lrb 

Several papers are in preparation to disseminate key findings related to the research results from multiple studies over several years of work in InquirySpace classrooms.
